page.title: 02SOIL AND TREES OF BEECHES
page.content: The Beeches area is divided by a deep valley running from East to West.The highest point is about 88metres,the lowest is 54metres.The soil is mainly clay and sand with some chalk,gravel and brick earth.Near the ponds'there is some boggy land.The Beeches dates back to Norman times.Pollarding,or lopping of the beech trees for firewood began about 1500 and went on to about 1820, when coal as fuel became available.In 1645 Cromwell ordered the trees to be pollarded into a domeshape.Today there are about 700 pollarded beech trees.The two oldest trees "The Druids Oak" and "His Majesty".The oak is about 450 years old and 9.2 m in girth and "H.M" is thought to be the oldest beech in England.
